content: The "Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015" prohibits providers of electronic communication services from disclosing communication contents to governmental entities. It eliminates the 180-day rule, requires a search warrant for disclosure, and mandates the disclosure of customer records. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015 prohibits providers from disclosing communication contents to governmental entities without a warrant issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. After receiving the contents of a wire or electronic communication, a governmental entity must serve the subscriber or customer with a copy of the warrant and a notice within a specified timeframe. This is in accordance with the Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015, which prohibits providers from disclosing communication contents without a court-issued warrant. A governmental entity can require a provider of electronic communication or computing service to disclose subscriber information with a warrant, court order, or customer consent, as outlined in the Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015 allows a provider of electronic communication service to disclose subscriber information in response to various types of subpoenas for law enforcement purposes. This includes providing the name, address, and telephone connection details of a subscriber engaged in telemarketing fraud. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015 allows disclosure of subscriber information to law enforcement without notice, including telephone connection records, service details, subscriber identity, and payment information. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015 allows governmental entities to use administrative subpoenas or grand jury subpoenas to require disclosure of electronic communication contents from originators, addressees, or service providers. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act Amendments Act of 2015 allows governmental entities to access electronic communications stored on their systems. Amendments to Section 2703(d) of title 18, United States Code, clarify court orders for disclosure under subsection (c) and remove references to wire or electronic communication contents. SEC. 4. DELAYED NOTICE. Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow a governmental entity to request a delay in notification for a warrant under section 2703(a) for up to 180 days for law enforcement agencies and 90 days for other entities if notification may endanger individuals or lead to flight from prosecution. The amended Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code allows a governmental entity to request a delay in notification for a warrant under section 2703(a) for up to 180 days for law enforcement agencies and 90 days for other entities if notification may endanger individuals or lead to flight from prosecution. Extensions of the delay can be granted upon request, and upon expiration of the delay, the governmental entity must serve notification. The amended Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code allows a governmental entity to request a delay in notification for a warrant under section 2703(a) for up to 180 days for law enforcement agencies and 90 days for other entities if notification may endanger individuals or lead to flight from prosecution. The entity must serve notification to the customer or subscriber by providing a copy of the warrant and informing them of the nature of the law enforcement inquiry with reasonable specificity, the information shared with the governmental entity, and the date of the warrant. The amended Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code allows a governmental entity to request a delay in notification for a warrant under section 2703(a) for up to 180 days for law enforcement agencies and 90 days for other entities. The entity must provide specific details such as the date of warrant service, notification delay, court authorization, and the relevant chapter provision for the delay. The amended Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code allows a provider of electronic communication service to delay notifying any other person of a warrant, order, or subpoena for up to 180 days for law enforcement agencies and 90 days for other governmental entities. The court may grant this request if there is a reason to believe that notification may endanger an individual's life, result in flight from prosecution, or lead to the destruction of evidence. The amended Section 2705 of title 18, United States Code allows a provider of electronic communication service to delay notifying any other person of a warrant, order, or subpoena for up to 180 days for law enforcement agencies and 90 days for other governmental entities. The court may grant this request if there is a reason to believe that notification may endanger an individual's life, result in flight from prosecution, or lead to the destruction of evidence, tampering with evidence, intimidation of witnesses, or seriously jeopardizing an investigation or unduly delaying a trial. Upon expiration of the delay period, the provider must notify the governmental entity before informing the customer or subscriber. The remote computing service must inform the governmental entity that obtained communication or information under section 2703 of their intent to notify the customer of any warrant, order, or subpoena. The term 'law enforcement agency' refers to agencies authorized to engage in criminal law enforcement. SEC. 5. EVALUATION BY THE GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2017, regarding the disclosure of customer communications and records under section 2703 of title 18, United States Code. The report will include an analysis of the use of section 2703 by law enforcement officers in obtaining information for criminal investigations. The report to Congress by the Comptroller General of the United States will analyze the average time taken by electronic communication service providers to comply with law enforcement requests under section 2703 of title 18, US Code. It will also detail the number of instances in the past 5 years where information was requested under a warrant from these providers. The report to Congress will analyze the time taken by electronic communication service providers to comply with law enforcement requests under section 2703 of title 18, US Code. It will also detail the number of instances in the past 5 years where information was requested under a warrant from these providers, along with an evaluation of disclosure under section 2703 of title 18, US Code. The report to Congress will analyze the effects of the amendments to the warrant requirements on judges and court operations, as well as the average time taken for electronic communication service providers to provide requested contents under a search warrant. It will also include the number of instances where providers were required to appear for failing to comply with a warrant. The report will analyze the effects of warrant requirement amendments on judges and court operations, including instances of providers failing to comply with warrants. It will also assess the use of emergency exceptions under section 2702(b)(8) of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 6. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. The Act does not prevent the US Government from acquiring wire or electronic communication contents or subscriber information under existing lawful authorities like the Wiretap Act or the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.
